repo.description: Parse and serialize minecraft packets, plus authentication and encryption.
repo.name: node-minecraft-protocol

body:
We all know having too much time is deadly. 

This is a fix for #66 , 1.7 support for node-minecraft-protocol. Featuring a cool new chat client in the examples. 

Many thanks to @deathcap for fixing a couple things left and right (squashing commits made his name disappear :[)

Here are some thoughts I had during the development of this patch : 
Minecraft protocol currently sends a lot of data as arrays, with a count prefix. Our current solution is to create a new parser for each array. It's a bit messy, and I think instead, we might as well create something along those lines : 

```javascript
0x01: [
  { name: "serverId", type: "string" },
  { name: "countPublicKey", type: "short" },
  { name: "publicKey", type: "byte", count: "countPublicKey" },
  { name: "countVerifyToken", type: "short" },
  { name: "verifyToken", type: "byte", count: "countVerifyToken" }
]
```

We would still need a tiny bit of boilerplate (if type is byte, then output it as buffer instead of array) but it would be a lot less code, and much cleaner code, than what we have right now. It would allow complex structures to be easily parsable. Also, might need a container type.

```javascript
0x26: [
  { name: "columnCount", type: "short" },
  { name: "dataCount", type: "int" },
  { name: "skylight", type: "bool" },
  { name: "data", type: "byte", count: "dataCount" },
  { name: "meta", type: "array", count: "columnCount", contents: [
    { name: "chunkX", type: "int" },
    { name: "chunkZ", type: "int" },
    { name: "bitMap", type: "short" },
    { name: "addBitMap", type: "short" }
  ]}
]
```

Since right now, MC Protocol gives us the length-prefix, I thought it might be a good idea to do opportunistic parsing. Right now, every parser is ran for every packets, even if there are no listeners. I didn't code that in yet because... well... I thought about it a little late, but performance should jump straight up if we were to implement such a feature.

Currently, longs are stored in an array, since they are too big to fit in a JavaScript Number. I think it might be a good idea to instead use a BigNumber library to store them in. I know node-minecraft-protocol strives to stay a low-level implementation, but seriously, manipulating a long as an array is just a headache. Luckily the minecraft protocol doesn't use longs all that much. But for instance time updates, which uses them, are a headache to parse right now.

comment_data.body: I had to change this to `jsonMsg.with[0].text` to get it to work.
I had to change this to `jsonMsg.with[1]`

This is kind of a misleading event name. Since events are strings this gets resolved to `"play,2"`. "play" is a made up word anyway; can we just have good names for these special events and then have 0x02 be the event name for that packet after the initial handshake is completed?
yup, fixing this right now. Seems like I failed during my rebasing.

@superjoe30 I don't see how how they are misleading ? The protocol now indexes packets using state and ID. I wanted to avoid using a string directly because they felt awkward (client.on("play,0x02") felt eaky) and settled to create a states enumlike so if you are to "mistype", you'd get a runtime error rather than no error at all (e.g. listening to a non-existant event).

Sure, creating special events for the few (5 ?) packets that aren't part of the PLAY state would work, but for one it feels like a lot of boilerplate for not much gain in the end ?

I wanted to have a system that is future proof. If we go for special event names, potential future changes to minecraft protocol might force us to crop up more "special events". Besides, the states enum is here in case mojang decides to add more states to the current protocol (unlikely, but not impossible either).

Of course, if you still prefer to have specially named packets, I'll just go ahead and do it. It just doesn't feel right to me.
I'd like to say that this example doesn't work against bukkit, since bukkit sends messages like { text: "", extra: ["<username> text"] } for some reason.

I will probably defer to your judgment at this point since you've been more intimate with the protocol than I have recently. But just to explain my perspective, the idea I have in my head is that minecraft-protocol would "eat" the first N packets during the handshake, status, and login steps, and then after that process is complete, the API consumer can listen to the 0x02 packets etc. In other words,  this library would handle packets in handshake, status, and login states, and the API consumer would only deal with the packets in "play" state. I'm pretty sure that's how it worked before.
I think that's OK, since it's just an example. Seems like it's a higher level module's problem to deal with the json chat message format.

> The way it worked before, using "require('minecraft-protocol').createClient()" would "eat" those packets to a certain point (you could still listen to them, but there was a default listener that would take care of all the logic), but using "new require('minecraft-protocol').Client()", you would only have a bareback client without any packet handler by default 

Ah yes now I remember. I'm sorry to be pushy, but I'm quite fond of this way (the way that it worked before). What is the benefit that switching to this new way with [state, packetId] thing?
After looking into it a lot more yesterday, I agree with your decision.

commit.message: Protocol 1.7 support, Yggdrasil login support, new Client State API

title: Feature mc1.7
